raw_text:
UK bank seals South Korean deal
 
 UK-based bank Standard Chartered said it would spend $3.3bn (£1.8bn) to buy one of South Korea's main retail banks.
 
 Standard Chartered said acquiring Korea First Bank (KFB) fulfilled a strategic objective of building a bigger presence in Asia's third largest economy. Its shares fell nearly 3% in London as the bank raised funds for the deal by selling new stocks worth £1bn ($1.8bn), equal to 10% of its share capital. Standard Chartered expects about 16% of future group revenue to come from KFB.
 
 The South Korean bank will also make up 22% of the group's total assets. The move, a year after Citigroup beat Standard Chartered to buy Koram bank, would be the South Korean financial sector's biggest foreign takeover. This time around, Standard Chartered is thought to have beaten HSBC to the deal. KFB is South Korea's seventh largest bank, with 3 million retail customers, 6% of the country's banking market and an extensive branch network.
 
 The country's banking market is three times the size of Hong Kong's with annual revenues of $44bn. Standard Chartered has its headquarters in London but does two thirds of its business in Asia, and much of the rest in Africa. "We're comfortable with the price paid...the key here has been speed and decisiveness in making sure that we won," said Standard Chartered chief executive Mervyn Davies at a London press conference. Standard Chartered said KFB was a "well-managed, conservatively run bank with a highly skilled workforce" and represented a "significant acquisition in a growth market". In London, Standard Chartered's sale of 118 million new shares to institutional investors pushed its share price down, and contributing to the FTSE 100's 0.3% decline. Standard Chartered's shares were 28 pence lower at 925p by midday. Some analysts also queried whether Standard Chartered had overpaid for KFB. The deal, which requires regulatory approval, is expected to be completed by April 2005 and to be earnings accretive in 2006, Standard Chartered said.
 
 Rival banking giant HSBC, which is based in London and Hong Kong, was also in the running. Standard Chartered is believed to have gained the initiative by putting together a bid during the Christmas break. "They were able to move so quickly it caught HSBC by surprise," the Financial Times newspaper quoted an insider in the talks as saying. HSBC will now have to wait for the next South Korean bank in line to be sold off - thought likely to be Korea Exchange Bank, also currently in the hands of a US group. Standard Chartered said it was buying 100% of KFB, an agreement that would bring an end to the bank's complex dual ownership. The South Korean government owns 51.4% of KFB, while the remaining shareholding, and operational control, are in the hands of US private equity group Newbridge Capital. Newbridge bought its stake during the government's nationalisation of several banks in the wake of the 1997 Asia-wide currency crisis which crippled South Korea's financial institutions.
 
 South Korea's economy is expected to grow by 4.5% this year. Although often thought of an export-driven economy, South Korea's service sector has overtaken manufacturing in the last decade or so. Services now make up roughly 40% of the economy, and consumer spending and retail banking have become increasingly important. In the aftermath of the Asian financial crisis, the government encouraged the growth of consumer credit. Bad loan problems followed; LG Card, the country's biggest credit card provider, has been struggling to avoid bankruptcy for months, for instance. But analysts believe South Korea's financial services industry is still in its infancy, offering plenty of scope for new products. Standard Chartered sees "the opportunity to create value by the introduction of more sophisticated banking products". Since 1999, KFB has been restructured from a wholesale bank into a retail bank focused on mortgage lending, which makes up 45% of its loans.

KFB will make up 22% of Standard Chartered's total assets, representing about 16% of future group revenue.

Standard Chartered expects 16% of future group revenue and 22% of total assets from KFB, which is South Korea's seventh largest bank with 3 million retail customers.

KFB is the seventh-largest bank in South Korea and will make up 22% of Standard Chartered's total assets, with approximately 16% of future group revenue projected from the acquisition. KFB will make up 22% of Standard Chartered's total assets, representing about 16% of future group revenue. The deal is expected to be completed by April 2005 and earnings accretive in 2006. The South Korean government owns nearly all of KFB, while the remaining shareholding and operational control are owned by US private equity group Newbridge Capital.

The deal is expected to add 22% of assets and generate about 16% of future group revenue from KFB. qwen2.5:3b: UK-based bank Standard Chartered announced it would spend £1.8bn to buy Korea First Bank (KFB), one of South Korea's main retail banks, to expand presence in the country’s economy. The deal is valued at $3.3bn and represents 22% of Standard Chartered’s total assets. KFB accounts for 6% of South Korea's banking market with 3 million retail customers. Standard Chartered CEO Mervyn Davies confirmed the purchase as a significant acquisition in a growth market, though some analysts questioned whether the price was overpriced. The deal has regulatory approval requirements and is expected to be completed by April 2005, potentially adding $1.8bn of future group revenue for Standard Chartered. This move marks South Korea’s largest foreign takeover in its financial sector.
opencoder:1.5b:
UK-based bank Standard Chartered bought Korea First Bank (KFB) to create a bigger presence in Asia's third largest economy. It plans to make up 22% of the group’s total assets. The South Korean government owns 51.4% of KFB, while the remaining shareholding, and operational control, are in the hands of US private equity group Newbridge Capital.

Standard Chartered's business model is focused on creating banking products that provide value to its customers. The country's economy has grown by 4.5% this year, with services now making up roughly 40% of the economy. Consumer spending and retail banking have become increasingly important in the aftermath of the Asian financial crisis.

The South Korean bank will also make up 22% of the group’s total assets, as this represents the country's largest foreign takeover. The move, a year after Citigroup beat Standard Chartered to buy Korea's first bank, would be the South Korean financial sector's biggest foreign takeover. This time around, Standard Chartered is thought to have beaten HSBC to the deal.

The company's shareholders hold the government's nationalisation of several banks in the wake of the 1997 Asian financial crisis which crippled South Korea’s financial institutions. The South Korean government encouraged the growth of consumer credit, and LG Card, the country’s biggest credit card provider, has been struggling to avoid bankruptcy for months. But analysts believe that South Korea's financial services industry is still in its infancy, offering plenty of scope for new products.

The South Korean bank also owns 51.4% of KFB, while the remaining shareholding and operational control, are in the hands of US private equity group Newbridge Capital.
smollm:1.7b:
The UK-based bank Standard Chartered said it would spend $3.3bn (£1.8bn) to buy one of South Korea's main retail banks. The deal is expected to be completed by April 2005 and will be earnings accretive in 2006, according to Standard Chartered.
South Korean bank KFB was also in the running for the deal. However, it is believed that Standard Chartered has gained the initiative by putting together a bid during the Christmas break.
The South Korean government owns 51.4% of KFB, while the remaining shareholding and operational control are in the hands of Newbridge Capital. Newbridge bought its stake during the government's nationalisation of several banks in the wake of the 1997 Asia-wide currency crisis which crippled South Korea's financial institutions.
South Korea's economy is expected to grow by 4.5% this year, according to the International Monetary Fund (IMF). Although often thought of an export-driven economy, South Korea's service sector has overtaken manufacturing in the last decade or so. Services now make up roughly 40% of the economy, and consumer spending and retail banking have become increasingly important.
In the aftermath of the Asian financial crisis, the government encouraged the growth of consumer credit. Bad loan problems followed; LG Card, the country's biggest credit card provider, has been struggling to avoid bankruptcy for months, for instance. However, analysts believe South Korea's financial services industry is still in its infancy, offering plenty of scope for new products. Since 1999, KFB has been restructured from a wholesale bank into a retail bank focused on mortgage lending, which makes up 45% of its loans.
South Korean banks are known for their strong credit standards and low default rates. However, the country's financial sector is still vulnerable to global economic shocks and must continue to diversify its economy in order to reduce its dependence on exports.
deepseek-r1:1.5b:
<think>
Alright, let's see what I need to do here. The user provided a pretty long paragraph about a UK-based bank buying a South Korean retail bank and wants me to summarize it concisely while preserving the key points.

First, I should read through the text carefully to identify the main elements: who is involved, what they're buying, where the deal goes, the financial implications for both banks, the timing of the acquisition, and any key statistics or details provided.

I know that Standard Chartered is spending $3.3 billion to buy Korea First Bank, which is a retail bank. The shares fell because they raised funds by selling stocks worth £1bn. They expect about 16% of their revenue from KFB and plan to make up 22% of the group's assets.

South Korea's banking market is quite large, three times bigger than Hong Kong's with $44 billion in revenue. The UK-based bank is a big player but not entirely new to South Korea; it already owns some banks there through Citigroup's deal and has another in the process.

HSBC, the rival, was in the running after combining their bid during the Christmas break. Now they have to wait for the next South Korean bank to sell off. The UK government is involved in nationalising other South Korean banks, focusing on financial services, especially consumer credit.

The economy is expected to grow, and while it's driven by exports, the service sector has overtaken manufacturing. Services make up 40%, with retail banking increasingly important after the crisis. KFB, a big retail bank, has been restructured as a mortgage lending bank, with bad loans still an issue for LG Card.

The acquisition of KFB offers opportunities in sophisticated products and is expected to generate value since KFB used to be a wholesale bank, switching focus to lending. There's also the note about the UK government's involvement in nationalising other banks.

I need to condense all this into a summary without adding any extra information beyond what was given. I should keep it clear and make sure key points like who bought what, revenue expectations, assets percentages, economic details are covered succinctly.
</think>

 uk-based Standard Chartered is considering purchasing South Korea's retail banking group Korea First Bank (KFB), estimated to bring significant value due to its restructuring from wholesale to retail lending focus. KFB was part of Citigroup's 2005 deal and now aims for a 16% revenue share in the UK financial sector, with KFB expected to make up 22% of the group's assets. The acquisition is seen as a significant foreign take by the South Korean government, with HSBC closing second place. The deal, pending regulatory approvals and targeting April 2005, will likely delay due to the timing of the next bank to sell off. KFB, South Korea's seventh largest bank at $13 billion revenue, is expected to increase its asset size and contribute to regional economic growth, while the UK government's involvement in nationalising other banks offers opportunities in consumer credit and financial services.
tinyllama:1.1b: UK-based bank Standard Chartered is acquiring South Korean bank Korea First Bank for $3.3bn (£1.8bn) in cash and new shares to boost its presence in Asia's third largest economy. The deal would fulfil a strategic objective of Standard Chartered's chief executive Mervyn Davies by making up 22% of the group's total assets. Standard Chartered's share price dropped after it announced the acquisition, but the news was not without controversy as rival banking giant HSBC also bid for the deal. Standard Chartered reportedly had to outdo HSBC in speed and decisiveness in making a decision on the purchase, which would bring an end to KFB's complex dual ownership. The South Korean government has overtaken manufacturing to become one of Asia's biggest service sectors, with consumer spendings and retail banks increasingly important. The news follows a similar deal between Standard Chartered and Koram bank in 2018 which was also approved by the UK's regulators.
tinydolphin:1.1b:
In November 2004, Standard Chartered completed the acquisition of South Korea's largest retail bank, Koram Bank. This transaction is expected to be the largest foreign takeover in South Korean history and marks a significant move for the British bank. 

Standard Chartered initially offered £1 billion ($1.8 billion) for the shares of Koram Bank, but increased its bid to £1.5 billion ($2.3 billion) in a bidding war with HSBC. South Korea's financial sector is growing rapidly due to government policies, and this deal would have provided Standard Chartered with an opportunity to enter the market at an early stage. The acquisition is expected to result in over £1 billion ($1.8 billion) of revenue for the bank within the first three years after the deal's completion.

Koram Bank has a diverse range of services and products, including retail loans, mortgages, and credit cards. The acquisition is expected to increase the bank's market share in the South Korean retail sector from its current position of seventh to first place. Standard Chartered now holds a 22% stake in the group's total assets, with revenues reaching £4.4 billion ($6.8 billion) per year. The deal is anticipated to be profitable for the bank, but it must still complete regulatory approval and earn its way into the market by providing investment opportunities for institutional investors. 

In London, Standard Chartered's shares were sold at £17 ($23) each, a premium of approximately £500 million ($694 million). The acquisition was seen as a strategic move in the bank's bid to capture a larger share of South Korea's rapidly growing financial sector. Standard Chartered plans to use the fundraised revenues to fund its growth plans and maintain its competitive edge in the market.

Standard Chartered will acquire 100% of KFB, while Newbridge Capital will still hold 51.4% of ownership and operational control.

The deal is due to be completed by April 2005 and is expected to be earnings accretive in 2006. Rival banking giant HSBC was also in the running, but Standard Chartered was able to move quickly and gain the initiative. The South Korean government owns 51.4% of KFB, while the remaining shareholding, and operational control, are in the hands of US private equity group Newbridge Capital.
